docs.lead_paragraph: The filmmakers Peter and Bobby Farrelly have been scrambling to rewrite dialogue and a final scene for the romantic comedy ''Fever Pitch,'' which is plotted around the love life of an obsessive Boston Red Sox fan (Jimmy Fallon) and his vain belief that his team will win a World Series. Whoops. ''When we made the movie, it was always, wink, wink, 'What if the year we make the movie is the year they win the World Series?''' said Elizabeth Gabler, the chief executive of Fox 2000, which is making the film for 20th Century Fox. The filmmakers shifted the story timeline to match the playoffs and inserted dialogue to account for Boston's World Series victory this week. They also shot a coda to the film, which has Mr. Fallon and his love interest, Drew Barrymore, above right, running onto the field at the real-life moment of the Red Sox historic triumph over St. Louis. ''It made for a magical fairy tale ending,'' Ms. Gabler said. SHARON WAXMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: Manny Ramirez could have been the most embarrassed player in the major leagues when he rejoined the Boston Red Sox in spring training. The Red Sox had tried to unload him. Take my left fielder and his massive contract, please, they begged, after placing Ramirez on irrevocable waivers. No one bit. Then the Red Sox were ready to send Ramirez to the Texas Rangers if they could have completed the trade for Alex Rodriguez. Obviously, they never did so, and Ramirez, who was basically available if someone was willing to pick up the $97.5 million he was owed, stayed with the Red Sox by default.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jay Pinkham, a salesman from Nashua, N.H., has a two-inch tattoo of two red socks, the logo of his star-crossed baseball team, on his right calf. In his heart is something even more indelible: an emotional bond to the team and its community of fans, who have loved and lost, and loved again -- and lost again -- every single summer, and the occasional fall, for 85 years. The bond is permanent, its effects extreme -- particularly this week, as the helium-happy ranks of Red Sox fans breathlessly watch their team try to make this October different from all those others, juggling the constant threat of misery with the cruelly tantalizing possibility of joy.

White Sox right fielder Magglio Ordonez was named as his replacement. Ramirez, who was the designated hitter last night against the Detroit Tigers, has been playing despite the injury. He was voted in by fans as an American League starter for the fifth year in a row. He has been named an All-Star seven times in all.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ted took his time leaving this world, and he's not quite out of it yet. He is cryonically frozen in Arizona, drained of blood and upside down but pretty much intact, waiting for what resurrection technology can eventually produce. This bizarre turn in the Williams saga, which two of his three children claim to be his own wish, accords with a general perception among his admirers that there was something about him extremely precious, something worth preserving. To those of us who saw him at the plate, he seemed the concentrated essence of baseball: a tall, long-necked man wringing the bat handle and snapping the slender implement of Kentucky ash back and forth, back and forth, in his impatience to hit the ball, to win the battle of wits and eye-hand coordination that, inning after inning, pits the solitary batter against the nine opposing men on the field.

docs.lead_paragraph: A song with profanity and drug-themed lyrics was broadcast over the Fenway Park loudspeakers before Manny Ramirez's first at-bat today, forcing the Red Sox to alter their policy on allowing players to choose their own music. Charles Steinberg, a team spokesman, said the song ''I Get High,'' by Styles, was requested during the game by a clubhouse attendant who was apparently relaying Ramirez's wishes. When the song was checked to make sure it was appropriate, it was not played all the way through.
